steps.title: Choose apples to use for making the fresh cider.
steps.content: Choose apples to use for making the fresh cider. You can use any type of apple and even use a combination of different apples. If you pick the apples right off the tree, let the apples age for 1 week. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Clean the apples under cool running water, washing them thoroughly.
steps.content: Clean the apples under cool running water, washing them thoroughly. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Core the apples and quarter them.
steps.content: Core the apples and quarter them. Use an apple corer to make this process quicker and easier. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Place the apple quarters into a blender, food processor or food chopper and process until smooth.
steps.content: Place the apple quarters into a blender, food processor or food chopper and process until smooth.

steps.title: Put the apple pulp into a porous fabric bag, such as a muslin sack or jelly bag, and squeeze out the juice into a bowl.
steps.content: Put the apple pulp into a porous fabric bag, such as a muslin sack or jelly bag, and squeeze out the juice into a bowl. Pour the liquid into glass bottles using a funnel, for ease.

steps.title: Fill the bottles to just below the rim and use a cotton plug.
steps.content: Fill the bottles to just below the rim and use a cotton plug. A cotton plug will pop out if too much pressure builds during the fermentation process, whereas a regular cap could make the bottle explode. Pressure builds when the bubbles from the carbon dioxide in the apple juice rise to the top of the bottle.

steps.title: Store the bottled juice at 72 degrees Fahrenheit (22 degrees Celsius) for 3 to 4 days.
steps.content: Store the bottled juice at 72 degrees Fahrenheit (22 degrees Celsius) for 3 to 4 days. Sediment will begin to form on the bottom of the bottles as a result of the fermentation process. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Strain the cider with a plastic strainer to separate the liquid and sediment.
steps.content: Strain the cider with a plastic strainer to separate the liquid and sediment. Discard the sediment, as this is not palatable.

steps.title: Pasteurize the fresh cider to prevent food born illnesses by heating it to 160 to 170 degrees Fahrenheit (71 to 77 degrees Celsius) in a stainless steel pot.
steps.content: Pasteurize the fresh cider to prevent food born illnesses by heating it to 160 to 170 degrees Fahrenheit (71 to 77 degrees Celsius) in a stainless steel pot. Skim the foam that forms on top due to the heat and discard.

steps.title: Fill heated glass bottles with the pasteurized cider and refrigerate.
steps.content: Fill heated glass bottles with the pasteurized cider and refrigerate. Drink the fresh cider within a week. [5] X Research source Freeze the fresh cider in glass or plastic freezer containers for up to 1 year after cooling the liquid down in the refrigerator.
